title-group.article-title: Enhanced active constrained layer damping (ACLD) treatment using stand-off-layer: robust controllers design, experimental implementation and comparison

article-meta.aff: Department of Industrial and Production Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Jalandhar, India

author-notes.corresp: Rajiv Kumar, Department of Industrial and Production Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Jalandhar, (Pb) – 144011, India Email: rajivsharma1972@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: It is a well known fact that system parameters of flexible structures keep on changing because of several reasons. Ordinary controllers lose their effectiveness in changed situations and do not guarantee the stability of the closed loop (CL) system. However, controllers designed based on robust control theory not only maintain the CL stability of the perturbed system for a large variation in system parameters but also maintain best performance. In this work, H∞ optimization based controllers are designed and implemented experimentally on a flexible beam with active constrained layer damping treatment. It is observed that H∞ loop shaping design procedure based controllers outperform linear quadratic Gaussian and standard H∞controllers both in terms of robust stability and robust performance. Relative merits and demerits of the controllers designed using μ- synthesis technique are also discussed. It has also been observed that time domain results also explain some of the important facts. Certain time domain parameters of the CL system prove the relative superiority of these controllers in terms of control energy utilization and robust performance.

sec.title: 1. Introduction and problem formulation
sec.p: It is a well known fact that all flexible structures are subjected to change in system parameters with the passage of time due to the change in operating conditions and environmental factors. Ordinary fixed controllers designed based on nominal parameters lose their effectiveness due to a variation in system parameters. To deal with this type of situation, an intensive effort is being made to implement the adaptive control and robust control techniques to active vibration control of smart structures. In this direction, in the field of adaptive vibration control, Zeng and Singh (1999) applied output feedback variable structure adaptive control to a flexible spacecraft. By using the neural network based adaptive control strategy; Youn et al. (2000) controlled the composite beam vibrations subjected to sudden de-lamination. Feedback controllers are suitable for random disturbances causing free vibrations. Shaw (2000) used self tuning regulators combined with minimum variance controller to control a spring mass system. Using classical positive position feedback control strategy, Rew (2002) suppressed multi-modal vibrations of flexible structures. Model predictive control is an indispensable control technique in process control. By using the adaptive predictive control strategy, Bai (2002) suppressed rotor vibrations. More recently, Lim et al. (2003) used adaptive bang-bang control for the vibration control of civil structures while seismic vibrations occur. Xiongzhu et al. (2003) used an ARMAX based identification and pole placement based controller for active vibration control of a smart beam.

Xu and Song (2004) developed a shape memory alloy wall joint which can adaptively attenuate and control the vibration wave propagation in cylindrical shells. Inthe previous work Kumar et al. (2005), experimental adaptive identification and control of a smart structurefeaturing piezoceramics based sensors/actuators were presented. An inverted L structure with surface bonded piezoceramic sensors/actuators was used for analysis, which is a partial representative of the radial drilling machine and selected compliance assembly robot arm (SCARA). It was assumed that the parameters of the smart structure were changing. Closed loop (CL), time domain identification of system parameters in auto-regressive moving average (ARMA) form, was proposed for the systems changing at slow rates. A thorough study was done to see the effect of updated system and controller parameters on system performance using adaptive control strategy.

Afterwards, extending the authors’ previous work on an inverted L structure it was observed that, to maintain stability, a different set of feedback control gains should be applied for free and forced vibration attenuation (Kumar et al., 2006). For forced vibrations, feedback controllers with certain optimum position of CL poles give maximum vibration reduction. By combining the feedback and feed forward controller (i.e. by using a hybrid controller), better transient performance can be obtained in the case of forced vibrations. By adapting the controller (feed forward and feedback) parameters the CL system performance remained excellent for large variations in system parameters. Further, a comparative study of adaptive controllers based on minimum variance, pole placement and linear quadratic techniques was presented (Kumar et al., 2006). It was observed that an adaptive controller based on pole placement technique requires high control effort and gives poor performance at and near the nominal system. But, it was observed that the linear quadratic control based adaptive controllers are noise tolerant and are free from abovementioned limitations.

Recently, it was investigated in detail (Kumar et al., 2007) that even the fixed controllers can become unstable, with large changes in system parameters. Robust control and adaptive control design techniques were investigated in this reference. Obviously, to obtain robust performance, it is desirable that the CL poles of the perturbed structure remain at pre-specified locations for a range of system parameters. For this, the controller designed to be based on the pole placement method is quite useful. In this work, the controllers based on adaptive and robust pole placement method were implemented on smart structures.

It has been known for a long time that stability is the main problem in adaptive control systems. For active vibration control problems, with a very fast system dynamics, this problem of stability becomes even more severe. In the very recent work of Kumar et al. (2007), this problem was reduced up to a certain extent, however certain conservatism was there. On the other hand, the modern robust controllers based on sophisticated H2 and H∞ optimization theory are free from such defects as discussed in Zhou et al. (1995). Like adaptive control of flexible structures, robust control of flexible structures emerged in early 90’s. In robust control methodology a central controller is designed which gives robust stability and performance for a family of systems with perturbed parameters. In this direction, Jee and Won (1994) used H∞ control design scheme based matrix fraction stability condition. A cantilever beam was used in the study. Kang et al. (1997) presented a robust vibration control for a flexible SCARA type robot manipulators based on μ -synthesis theory.

Baz (1998) developed the robust controller for an active constrained layer damping (ACLD) treated beam by minimizing the H2-norm of the transfer functions between the external disturbances and the deflections at critical locations along the structure to guarantee optimal disturbance rejection capabilities. Afterwards, Crassidis et al. (2000) compared the performance of H∞ controllers at different operating frequencies and temperatures with that of conventional proportional/derivative controllers emphasizing the superiority of the former over the latter. Chang et al. (2002) presented a model reduction method and uncertainty modeling for the design of a low order H∞ robust controller for suppression of smart panel vibrations. The results of H∞ controller were compared with simple displacement proportional feedback controller and showed the supremacy of the former controller.

In the case of ACLD treated structures, active control is more effective, as sufficient passive damping is always available from passive constrained layer damping (PCLD) treatment. Also, for ACLD based systems the difference between theoretical and experimental results is higher. So, there is a need to develop controllers which are robust to these parametric errors. The natural choice is to look for a robust controller. Working in the same direction, Li et al. (2003) used μ -synthesis technique for the vibration control of plate – like structures. They showed the superior performance of the μ -synthesis based controllers over the H∞ robust controller. Liu et al. (2004) designed and implemented H∞ robust controller to accommodate uncertainties of the ACLD parameters, particularly those of the viscoelastic damping core which arise from the variation of operating temperature and frequency. Xie et al. (2004) investigated the robust vibration control of a thin plate covered with a controllable constrained layer damping. Caracciolo et al. (2005) developed a robust controller based on mixed H2/H∞ optimization which allows trading explicitly between nominal performance and robust stability. By simulations they proved the effectiveness of the designed controller on a four bar linkage mechanism with all the links flexible. Hu and Ng (2005) designed and applied robust controllers to suppress the vibrations of a circular plate. Stavroulakis et al. (2006) reduced rotor system vibrations using magnetic bearings. They demonstrated that the proposed approach was effective for vibration suppression when the system is subjected to impulsive and step loading, speed variation and sudden loss of disk masses. Very recently, Lim (2008) proposed a linear matrix inequality based robust controller for an active mass damper. The applicability of the robust saturation controller was verified through experimental tests on a model of a multi-storey building.

In almost all the above stated works, performance quantification was done in frequency domain only. Time domain characteristics (like settling time, r.m.s. amplitude of output and control energy utilized in driving the actuators etc.) were not studied in full detail. For the same CL performance in frequency domain, there is quite a big difference in performance in time domain. Also, in past, for robust vibration control of smart structures, H∞ and μ-synthesis based controllers have been generally tried and that too independently. H∞ loop shaping design procedure (H∞-LSDP) is an important robust control methodology. In the present work H∞-LSDP based robust controller has been applied and the results are compared with and linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG), standard H∞ and μ-synthesis based controllers both in frequency as well as in time domain. Relative merits and demerits of each controller are discussed. The second contribution of the present work is the introduction of a systematic approach for modeling the system in linear fractional transformations (LFT) form. The real parametric uncertainties can be easily quantified by using this method. Use of feed through term in system identification, eliminates the need to consider the unmodeled dynamics. This eliminates the need to specify uncertainty weighing functions. However, a systematic method has also been used for the selection of performance weighing functions, which are used in the design of these controllers with fine tuning capability to reduce the amplitude of a specific mode of vibration by desired amount.

This feature is generally not available with standard techniques of weighing function selection (Zhou et al, 1995). Based on LFT modeling presented, it is easy to separate the real and complex uncertainties, which are very difficult, by using standard techniques of model reduction on the models obtained from finite element method (FEM) techniques (Kumar et al., 2005). Using this factor, it is possible to reduce the amplitude of each targeted mode with desired amount so that genuine comparison of different control methodologies could be made. With slight modifications, this study will be useful in the control of adaptive and smart rotating structures such as rotorcraft blades. This study will also be useful in the control of rotating structures like rotating connected beams which are used in the analysis of space structures. The proposed control schemes can also be used for the control rotating plates and shells, flexible link manipulators and high speed helicopter blades.

sec.title: 2.1. Finite element modeling
sec.p:
A simply supported beam treated with ACLD treatment using a stand-off-layer (SOL) is taken for the present study. AnFEM based model of the structural system is obtained by using energy principles along with Hamilton method. An aluminum beam of dimensions 300 mm × 30 mm × 4 mm has been used for the experimental system. Its density as well as Young’s modulus of elasticity is given as 2700 Kg/m3 and 70 GPa respectively. A constraining layer made of steel with thickness of 0.5 mm is applied. The thickness of the viscoelastic layer and stand-off-layer is taken as 1 mm each. The density and shear modulus of the viscoelastic layer is 2000 Kg/m3 and 0.9 MPa respectively. The beam was divided into 15 elements. For more clarity about nodal displacement and shape functions, refer to any standard paper on ACLD treatment. The electrical properties of the actuator and sensor materials are given in Table 1. Aclose relationship has been obtained between theoretical and experimental results. The boundary conditions of the system are also subjected to change with the passage of time, environment and other factors. This can cause significant change in system parameters. Classical control design systems can cause instabilityand performance degradation of the CL system. Modern robust control theory has the answer to these problems. To design these types of controllers, the system variations from the nominal system are calculated. First of all, assume the case of a fixed-fixed treated beam. All the three degrees of freedom at each end of the beam are fixed. But, perfectly rigid boundary conditions are not available in real life. To simulate these boundary conditions, another method is applied as shown in Figure 1. The beam is allowed to move axially. Figure 1.
Schematic view of the clamped beam with variable boundary conditions.
Table 1.
Material properties of the sensor and actuator materials
Property Symbol Value
PZT PVDF
Piezoelectric charge constant (m V-1) d31 171 × 10-12 22 × 10-12
Electromechanical coupling factor k31 — 0.12
Piezoelectric voltage constant (VmN-1) g31 — 216 × 10-3
Dielectric constant k3t — 12

When the bolts are not tightened, the beam will be under simply supported beam conditions. If the bolts are tightened to a high value such that the slope formed at the free ends is zero and the beam behaves as a fixed-fixed beam with axial movement allowed. Under the various loads, applied by tightening the loads, different boundary conditions can be developed artificially. Table 2 shows the values of natural frequencies and damping ratios under different boundary conditions Table 3 shows the values of the product of mode shapes and feed through term. In the FEM approach, the actual system (i.e. flexible structure) is modeled as n-degree-of-freedom mechanical system whose generalized co-ordinates are represented by a n × 1 vector q and n × n mass matrix M and stiffness matrix K; both matrices are positive definite and symmetric. The equation of motion is given as (1)Mq··+Kq=f where f is the n × 1 vector of generalized co-ordinates. Since the matrix K is a complex matrix, equation (1) cannot be used directly for controller design and simulation purpose using standard simulation tools. Although certain methods are available (like Golla-Hughes-McTavish (GHM), Biot method etc) in which K is a real matrix, certain other problems are encountered. In these approaches damping matrix D comes into the picture to accurately represent the dynamics of the system. This matrix D is not a symmetric matrix (Zhou et al., 1995) and causes problems in model reduction techniques. System identification based model order reduction is applied in the present work which is discussed very briefly in the next subsection. System matrices A, B, C and D are given in the Appendix for the nominal system. Table 2.
Damping parameters (frequency and damping ratio) under different boundary conditions
Property Mode 1 Mode 2 Mode 3 Mode 4
Frequency (Hz) Damping ratio Frequency (Hz) Damping ratio Frequency (Hz) Damping ratio Frequency (Hz) Damping ratio
Nearly SS 98.5 0.025 396.4 0.015 920.3 0.011 1565.5 0.008
Intermediate-1 190.6 0.015 541.7 0.011 1122.6 0.009 1815.1 0.007
Nearly FF with axial movement 215.3 0.015 601.1 0.011 1236.6 0.009 1994.5 0.006
Table 3.
Damping parameters (product of mode shapes and feed through term) under different boundary conditions
Property Product Feed through term
Mode 1 Mode 2 Mode 3 Mode 4
Nearly SS 2015.4 24815.8 5533.2 465267.1 0.07
Intermediate 4150.1 48947.6 464.5 516575.3 0.08
Nearly FF with axial movement 5082.2 65191.6 876.3 556671.4 0.07

sec.title: 2.2. Grey box subspace system identification
sec.p: Even though matrix K is complex, it is easy to construct the frequency response function (FRF) from the input-to-output data using M and K matrices with the help of standard MATLAB toolboxes. Reduced order system transfer function can be identified from FRF data using standard system identification methods. Another advantage of this technique is that experimentally obtained FRF can be clubbed with FEM results to construct more realistic models of the dynamic system. It has been observed that sub-space based models are more useful in designing the controller as compared topolynomial based models (Kumar and Singh, 2006a,b). If the subspace (state space) model has certain physically meaningful parameters like natural frequencies, damping rations and mode shapes, it would be helpful in the construction of system parameters with real parametric uncertainties (Zhou et al., 1995). The system can be written in the form written as below (2a)x·(t)=Ax(t)+Bu(t)=(0I-Ω-Λ)x(t)+(0B2)u(t) (2b)y(t)=Cx(t)=(B2T0)x(t) where Ω and Λ∈ℝn×n, and B2∈ℝn×m has to be estimated if inputs and outputs are collocated, which is there in our present work. Here m represents the number of inputs of the system. For a single input single output (SISO) system, with single mode consideration, the above model can be written as (3)x·(t)=(01-ω2-2ξω)x(t)+(0φ12)u(t)y(t)=(10)x(t) where ω, ξ and φ are the natural frequency, damping ratio and mode shape (of the considered mode) of the structure at the location where actuator is attached respectively. φ12 is obtained by multiplying the mass normalized mode shapes at the sensor and actuator location. By considering the various modes of interest, the model above can be extended to multi mode case easily. The frequencies and damping ratios are available by solving the eigenvalue problem from global mass andstiffness matrices using standard methods. Now, by using these parameters, φ12 for each mode will be calculated. Let G(jω) represents the FRF of the continuous time system obtain from FEM data. Since ours isacollocated system the FRF can be written as (Ljung, 1999) (4)G(jω)=∑i=1nΨi(jω)iφ12=∑i=1nΨi(jω)Ri where Ri=iφ12 is the residue matrix corresponding toith mode. It can be calculated using the following equation (Cavallo et al., 2007) (5)ΞR=ϒ where (6)Ξ=(Ψ1(jω1)IpΨ2(jω1)Ip…Ψn(jω1)IpΨ1(jω2)IpΨ2(jω2)Ip…Ψn(jω2)Ip::…:Ψ1(jωM)IpΨ2(jωM)Ip…Ψn(jωM)Ip)∈ℂmm×mn Ip is a unity matrix with appropriate dimensions considering number of inputs and outputs. (7)R=(R1R2:Rn)∈ℝmn×m (8)ϒ=(G(ω1)G(ω2):G(ωM))∈ℂpm×m
Since (9)R=XT(ReΨImΨ),where X=(ReΞImΞ)

For more clarity reader is directed to reference (Cavallo et al., 2007). Using the above approach system can be modeled in state space form given by equation (2) as is shown in Figure 2. This figure shows how we can accurately identify the system using feed through term by correcting the model shown in relation equation (2b) by the following equation (10)y(t)=Cx(t)+D u(t)=(B2T0)x(t)+D u(t) by iteratively varying the value of D from zero to certain positive constant until the FRF of the identified model matches with the obtained from FEM analysis. The main advantage of this type of modeling technique is that the effect of higher modes on the low order model can easily be considered. This eliminates the need to consider the unmodeled dynamics in controller design. Hence complex uncertainties need not to be considered in this case (Zhou et al.,1995). Now we are able to represent the uncertain system in a new form represented below: Figure 2.
Frequency domain comparison of identified models with and without using feed through term Linear Fractional Transformation representation for a single mode.
Figure 3.
LFT representation for a single mode.

sec.title: 2.3. Linear fractional transformation model of uncertain system
sec.p: It is a common practice to represent the system uncertainties as LFT forms to design robust controllers. Every single mode of a structural system is represented in transfer function form by equation (11)yu=φ12s2+2ξωs+ω2 where φ12, ξ and ω represent the product of mode shapes at actuator and sensor locations, damping ratio and natural frequency of the structural system. All the parameters are subjected to change around some nominal values like (12)φ12=M_p(1+pφ12d_p) (13)2ξω=M_2damp(1+p2ξωd_2damp) (14)ω=M_w(1+pωd_w) and (15)ω2=M_ww(1+pω2d_ww) with M_p, M_2damp, M_w and M_ww as nominal values of φ12, 2ξω, ω and ω2 respectively. d_p, d_2damp, d_w and d_ww are corresponding perturbations around the nominal values. The perturbed parameters can be written in the form as (Zhou et al., 1995) (16)[y_pv_p]=[0M_ppφ12M_p][u_pu] (17)[y_wv_w]=[0M_wpωM_w][u_wx·] (18)[y_wwv_ww]=[0M_wwpω2M_ww][u_wwx] (19)[y_2dampv_2damp]=[0M_2dampp2ξωM_2damp][u_2dampv_w] (20)u_p=d_p×y_p (21)u_w=d_w×y_w (22)u_ww=d_ww×y_ww (23)u_2damp=d_2damp×y_2damp forming a standard configuration to represent the uncertain system. The perturbation block Δ, corresponds to parameter variations and are called parametric uncertainties. The uncertain matrix Δ is not a full matrix but a diagonal one like (24)Δ=[Δ10000Δ200:::000Δ17]

In this manner, the real and complex uncertainties can be separated easily. The system uncertainties can be represented in the form of real parameter uncertainties as compared to complex uncertainties which are normally available from FEM based models. Due to this fact, the controllers designed by considering first type of uncertainties only are better in terms of robust stability and performance as compared to later. The parametric uncertainties described in this form eliminate the need of selecting uncertainties weighing functions. The selection of these weighing functions is a tedious task (Zhou et al., 1995).

By adding different modes as shown in Figure 4 the model can be generated for multiple modes.W1 and W2 are the weighing transfer functions used for controller design. W1 is the performance weighing function and W2 is the control weighing function. For each mode the weighing function should be chosen as Nns2+2ξnωns+ωn2.

By choosing Nn for the nth mode, modal amplitude reduction can be regulated. In a similar way, the complete weighing function can be obtained by connecting these individual modal weighing functions in parallel. The control weighing function is taken as a scalar constant by hit and trial. After a minor effort we can easily design these functions and efficient controllers. This method of weighing function is quite different from that available in the general literature on robust control (Zhou et al., 1995). Figure 4.
Input/output block diagram of the flexible structure with multiple modes along with a controller.

The interconnection transfer matrix M is portioned as M=[M11M12M21M22] where the dimensions of M11 confirm with those of Δ (Figure 5). By routine manipulations it can be shown that (25)z=[M22+M21Δ(I-M11Δ)-1M12]w and the following relations are available as per Figure 6. Now G considering Δ as an integral part, being represented as P as (26)P=[P11(s)P12(s)P21(s)P22(s)] Figure 5.
Standard M-Δ configuration.
Figure 6.
Standard H∞ configuration.

Referring Figure 7 and using w = r, z=[z1z2]=[eu] y = e and u = u, the interconnected system becomes (27)P=[I-G0II-G] Figure 7.
Mixed sensitivity configuration.
By considering z1 = W1e and z2 = W2u, optimization problem is now given as (28)minKstabilizing‖‖(I+GK)-1K(I+GK)-1‖‖∞ which becomes (29)minKstabilizing‖‖W1(I+GK)-1W2K(I+GK)-1‖‖∞
These weighting functions can be easily absorbed into the interconnected system P(s), as in this case, (30)P=[W1-W1G0W2I-G]

Let the state-space description of the generalized (interconnected) system P(s) in Figure 7 be given by: (31)x·(t)=Ax(t)+B1w(t)+B2u(t)z(t)=C1x(t)+D11w(t)+D12u(t)y(t)=C2x(t)+D21w(t)+D22u(t)} where x(t)∈ℝn is the state vector, w(t)∈ℝm1 the exogenous input vector, u(t)∈ℝm2 the control input vector, z(t)∈ℝp1 the error (output) vector, and y(t)∈ℝp2the measurement vector, with p1>m2andp2>m1. P(s) may be further denoted as (32)P(s)=[P11(s)P12(s)P21(s)P22(s)]=[AB1B2C1D11D12C2D21D22]=:[ABCD]

Choosing ‘r’ as reference, ‘n’ as noise and ‘d’ as disturbance, it can be shown that (Zhou et al., 1995) (33)y=(I+GK)-1GKr+(I+GK)-1d-(I+GK)-1GKn (34)u=K(I+GK)-1r-K(I+GK)-1d-K(I+GK)-1n (35)e=(I+GK)-1r-(I+GK)-1d-(I+GK)-1n

We have to minimize the ∞-norm of the gain of the CL system. Now to design a controller K that minimizes ‖‖(I+GK)-1‖‖∞ for good tracking and minimizes ‖‖K(I+GK)-1‖‖∞ for less control energy. In the presence of these conflicting objective functions one has to design the optimal controller. In the LFT form it can be written as z=Fl(P,K)w i.e. z=[P11+P12K(I-P22K)-1P21]w in the presence of controller K. The design objective now becomes (36)minKstablizing |Fl(P,K) |∞ and this is referred as H∞ optimization problem.

sec.title: 3.1. Linear quadratic Gaussian control
sec.p: The controller design using Linear Quadratic Regulator is discussed in this section. Due to various uncertainties, the system dynamics is not constant. LQG control is an excellent robust control system design methodology. Let the system to be controlled can be written in state-space form given below (37)X·(t)=AX(t)+B2u(t)y(t)=C2X(t)+D22u(t)}
Using the gain matrix K control inputs are calculated by the following equation (38)u(t)=-k X(t)

The system matrices A and B and the weighing matrices R and Q are used to calculate the gain matrix K. The relative amplitude of the elements of these matrices determines the amplitude of the control signal vector u(t). Before designing the controller, theobservability and controllability must be checked by calculating the observability and controllability Gramians.

sec.title: 3.2. H∞ Controller design
sec.p: The H∞ solution formulae use solutions of two algebraic Riccati equations (ARE). An ARE (40)ETX+XE-XWX+Q=0 where W = WT and Q = QT, uniquely correspond to a Hamiltonian matrix [E-W-Q-ET] The stabilizing solution X, if it exists, is a symmetric matrix which solves the ARE and is such that E-W X is a stable matrix. The stabilizing solution is denoted as: (41)X=Ric[E-W-Q-ET]
Defining (42)Rn=D1*TD1*-[γ2Im1000]Z (43)R~n=D*1TD*1-[γ2Ip1000] where (44)D1*=[D11D12]and D*1=[D11D21]
Assume Rn and R~n are non-singular. We define two Hamiltonian matrices H and J as: (45)H=[A0-C1TC1-AT]-[B-C1TD1*]Rn-1[D1*TC1BT] (46)J=[AT0-B1B1T-A]-[CT-B1DT]R~n-1[D*1B1TC]
Let (47)X=Ric(H) (48)Y=Ric(J)

Based on X and Y, a state feedback matrix F and an observer gain matrix L can be constructed, which will be used in the solution formulae, (49)F=-Rn-1(D1*TC1+BTX)=:[F1F2]=[F11F12F2] (50)L=-(B1D*1T+YCT)R~n-1=:[L1 L2]=[L11 L12 L2] where F1, F2, F11 and F12 are of m1, m2, m1 - p2 and p2 rows, respectively and L1, L2, L11 and L12 of p1, p2, p1 - m2 and m2 columns, respectively. Using these values of Ls and Fs the central controller K can be designed (Zhou etal., 1995).

sec.title: 3.3. H∞Loop shaping controller design
sec.p:
The H∞ robust stabilization against such perturbations and the consequently developed design method, the H∞ LSDP (Zhou etal., 1995), could relax the restrictions on the number of right-half plane poles and produce no pole-zero cancellations between the nominal model and controller designed. This method does not require an iterative procedure to obtain an optimal solutionandthus raises the computational efficiency. This LSDP can be carried out in the following steps (Zhou etal., 1995).
Using a pre-compensator, W1, and/or a post-compensator, W2, as depicted in Figure 8, the singular values of the nominal system G are modified to give a desired loop shape. Usually, the least singular value of the weighted system should be made big over the low frequency range to achieve good performance such as the tracking, the largest singular value small over high frequency range to deal with unmodeled dynamics, and the bandwidth affects the system response speed while the slope of the singular values near the bandwidth frequency should not be too steep. The nominal system and weighting functions W1 and W2 are combined to form the shaped system, Gs, where Gs = W2GW1. It is assumed that W1 and W2 are such that Gs contain no hidden unstable modes.
A feedback controller, Ks, is synthesized which robustly stabilizes the normalized left co prime factorization of Gs, with a stability marginɛ. It can be shown (Zhou etal., 1995) that if ɛ is not less than 0.2, the frequency response of KsW2GW1 will be similar to that of W2GW1. On the other hand, if the achievable ɛ is too big, that would probably indicate an over-designed case in respect of the robustness, which means that the performance of the system may possibly be improved by using a larger γ in computing Ks.
The final feedback controller, Kfinal, is then constructed by combining the H∞ controller Ks, with the weighting functions W1 and W2 such that (Zhou etal., 1995)
(51)Kfinal=W1KsW2 Figure 8.
One degree of freedom LSDP consideration.

sec.title: 3.4. Stability and performance considerations
sec.p: The following theorem is generally encountered in robust control literature.

Theorem 1: For stable G(s), the closed-loop system is robustly stable if K(s) stabilizes the nominal plant and the following holds (Zhou etal., 1995) (52)‖‖K(I+GK)-1||∞<1 or, in a strengthened form, (53)‖‖K(I+GK)-1||∞<1 |Δ |∞

Writing in other way, let (54)M(P,K)=LFT(P,K)=Fl(P,K)=[P11P12P21P22]+[P13P23]K(I-P33K)-1[P31P32] such that M=[M11M12M21M22] in such a way that M is an interconnected CL transfer function matrix M (s). Then for any structured uncertainty Δ we have the following indications (Zhou etal., 1995) for structured uncertainty Δ(55a)Robust Performance⇔ ||M ||μ<1 (55b)Robust Stability⇔ ||M11 ||μ<1 (55c)Nominal Performance⇔ ||M22 ||μ<1 (55d)Nominal Performance⇔M is internally stable
The meaning of the term ||M ||μ means that μΔ(M(s))=supω∈[0,∞]μΔ(M(jω)) at all the frequencies ω, the structured singular value should be less than one.

sec.title: 3.5. μ Controller design by D-K iteration method
sec.p: For robust stability and robust performance, it is required to find a stabilizing controller K such that (56)supω∈ℝμ[M(P,K)(jω)]<1

An iterative method was proposed to solve (58) in Zhou etal. (1995). The method is called the D-K iteration μ-synthesis method and is based on solving the following optimization method, for a stabilizing controller K and a diagonal constant scaling matrix D, (57)infK(s) sup infD∈Dω∈ℝσ¯[DM(P,K)D-1(jω)] where the scaling matrix set D is defined in Zhou etal. (1995). Shortly μ-synthesis algorithm is given as:
Start with an initial guess for D, usually D = I.
Fix D and solve H∞ optimization for K,
K=arginfK |Fl(P,K) |∞
Fix K and solve convex optimization problem for D at each frequency over a selected frequency range,
D(jω)=arginfD∈Dσ¯[DFl(P,K)D-1(jω)]
Curve fit D(jω) to get a stable, minimum phase D(s).
Go to step 2 and repeat until a prespecified convergence is achieved.

sec.title: 4. Experimental setup
sec.p: The experimental setup is shown in Figure 1. The controller was implemented using a dSPACE DS1103 rapid prototyping Controller board together with a MATLAB and SIMULINK environment. The sampling frequency was setup in the range 7–10 kHz, while the cut-off frequency of both the low pass filters was setup at 2,500 Hz. A high voltage amplifier MA – 17 from Apex Technologies was capable of driving highly capacitive loads was used to supply necessary voltage for actuating the piezoelectric patch.

sec.title: 5.1. Frequency domain
sec.p:
First of all the nominal system corresponding to intermediate system with zero pre-stress conditions as in Table 2 is chosen. Systems corresponding to nearly simply supported and nearly fixed-fixed boundary conditions are taken as the perturbed systems around the nominal system. The intermediate boundary conditions at which the first four natural frequencies are 190.6, 541.7, 1122.6 and 1815.1 Hz is chosen as nominal system. Perturbed system – I is taken with boundary conditions as nearly fixed-fixed, and the perturbed system – II is taken with boundary conditions as nearly simply supported with first four natural frequencies as 98.5, 396.4, 920.3 and 1565.5 Hz. Using Figures 3 and 4 the perturbed systems are modeled in LFT form. LQG, standardH∞, H∞LSDP and MU synthesis based controller are designed by using weighing functions in such a way that the CL nominal system with these controllers is as shown in Figure 9. In the CL system the reduction in amplitude is 4 dB, 6 dB, 8.5 dB for the first, second and fourth mode respectively. The magnitude at the third mode is negligible and hence is not apparent in this figure. The ordinary position feedback controller is capable of amplitude reduction at first mode very well. However, for other modes its amplitude reduction capability decreases. Hence it is not included in the comparison. Figure 9.
Frequency response function of nominal open and closed loop system with different controllers.

R and Q matrices for LQG controller are taken such that R = 1 and Q is a diagonal matrix with diagonal terms as a vector of [1.1, 0, 0.27, 0, 0, 0, 0.25, 0] × 5 x102. Other elements of this matrix are zero. Weighing transfer functions for H∞ is chosen such that inverse of this transfer function always lies above the nominal sensitivity function S (Figure 10) and the CL nominal system matches with that in Figure 9. Forfirst, second and fourth modes it is selected as 5.02x103s2+2ξ1ω1s+ω12, 5.92x104s2+2ξ2ω2s+ω22 and 6.81x105s2+2ξ4ω4s+ω42 respectively. The overall weight function is calculated by joining the above three transfer functions in parallel. The pre-filter for H∞LSDP controller is chosen with similar considerations (Figure 11). Intransfer function form it is 8(s+1)0.9s. For the MU controller, an almost similar weighing function as used in standard H∞ controller, is used. The comparison of standard H∞, H∞ LSDP and MU controllers in frequency domain are shown in Figure 12. The gains of standard H∞ controller are slightly higher than for H∞ LSDP based controller. This corresponds to a larger bandwidth of the later leading to slightly faster dynamics of the corresponding CL system. The gains of the MU controller have the highest value. Figure 13 shows the robust stability at different frequencies for the perturbed CL system with the standard H∞ controller. The CL perturbed system with standard H∞ control is robustly stable at all the frequencies. Corresponding graphs for LSDP and MU controllers are shown in Figures 14 and 15 respectively. Standard H∞ control shows a very minute instability as μ value exceeds 1. Figure 10.
Comparison nominal sensitivity function and inverse weighing function used for H∞ controller.
Figure 11.
Comparison of frequency response of the original system and shaped system for H∞ loop shaping controller.
Figure 12.
Frequency response function of simple H∞, H∞ LSDP and H∞ MU controllers.
Figure 13.
Plot for robust stability of the closed loop system with H∞ controller.
Figure 14.
Plot for robust stability of the closed loop system with H∞ loop shaping controller.
Figure 15.
Plot for robust stability of the closed loop system with H∞ MU controller.

Nominal performance is established at all the frequencies by all the controllers as μ value is less than unity. However, performance of the perturbed CL system degrades as μ value reaches above unity for some frequencies (Table 4). Figure 16 shows the nominal and robust performance at different frequencies for the perturbed CL system with standard H∞ controller. Figure 17 shows the pole zero maps, for standard H∞, H∞ LSDP and MU controllers. All the three controllers are stable (because all the poles are on the left hand plane) as well as stabilizing (i.e. the CL system is stable). From this plot it is obvious that one pole isalways at the origin and the second pole always at (−1, 0) for the H∞LSDP controller. Presence of one pole at origin indicates the strong stability of the H∞ LSDP controller (Zhou etal., 1995). Due to this fact the LSDP controllers do not saturate the control system at the start up which is normally there for standard H∞ controllers. For the latter to obtain the properties like H∞ LSDP controller, another type of synthesis as discussed in Zhou etal. (1995) has to be applied. However, this problem can also be eliminated by constraining the amplitude of the applied input which is actually done in the present work. Figure 16.
Plot for comparison of nominal and robust performance with H∞ controllers.
Figure 17.
Pole zero maps for the simple H∞, H∞ LSDP and H∞ MU controllers.
Table 4.
Comparison of mu-values of different modes for nominal and robust performance
mu-values Nominal performance Robust performance
H-infinity LSDP MU H-infinity LSDP MU
Mode 1 0.56 0.45 0.53 2.04 1.51 2.11
Mode 2 0.61 0.52 0.57 2.34 1.79 1.84
Mode 3
Mode 4 0.71 0.64 0.72 1.37 1.51 1.54

Based on the robust control theory, it is preferred to have minimum μ value for robust performance. The performance of the perturbed CL system degrades less severely as μ value of MU controller reaches near 1.84 as compared to 2.34 in the case of the standard H∞ controller. The corresponding value for LSDP controller is 1.79 (Table 4). So, the LSDP controller should be most efficient. The fact is not practically visible. Figure 18 shows the performance of different controllers in frequency domain, when applied to the perturbed system-II. The amplitude of the first and third mode is much less, and hence not visible in this figure. Amplitude reduction capability of LSDP based controller is slightly better as compared to standard H∞ controller. MU controller is best in terms of modal amplitude reduction for the second and fourth modes (which are actually dominant) as seen from this Figure (observe amplitude reduction in dB for all the controllers). However, μ value based analysis says something different. Based on these observations, it is obvious that frequency domain results alone cannot explain all the facts. Figure 18.
Frequency response function of perturbed open and closed loop system with different controllers.

sec.title: 5.2. Time domain
sec.p:
To check the system in time domain using various controllers, the output as well as input of the open loop (OL) and CL system is compared. The system is displaced from its equilibrium in such a way that all the modes are excited. This can be done practically by pressing the beam at certain locations. Figures 19 and 20 show the output response and the applied input. Table5 shows important time domain parameters. First of all the settling time will be considered. The settling time of the system has been taken here as the time required forthe final amplitude of vibration to approach 5% of the initial amplitude. Since no initial velocity is given to the system, initial amplitude can be easily quantified. For the nominal system, OL settling time is 0.8 second for a constant initial excitation. CL settling time obtained with LQG, standard H∞ and H∞ LSDP controllers is constant with a value of 0.37, 0.41 and 0.42 second respectively. With MU controller, the settling time is 0.41. The strength or power of a signal is dependent on the sum of the squares of its amplitude for a given period of time. Hence the sum of the squares of the OL system is 1.14 × 103 volt2 with initial excitation. The strength of the output signal for the CL system with LQG controller is 1.10 × 103 volt2. The corresponding values with H∞ and H∞LSDP controller are 0.56 × 103 and 0.58x103 respectively. The corresponding value for MU controller is 0.54 × 103. By comparing standard H∞ and H∞LSDP controllers, it is obvious that the performance is nearly same for the nominal system chosen in terms of settling time. The strength of the output signal by H∞LSDP controller (with strength 0.580 × 103) is comparable to that with standard H∞ controller (with strength 0.56 × 103). The peak voltage required at the actuator side is nearly 20 volt, for all the controllers. Figure 19.
Time domain performance comparison of the nominal closed loop system with various controllers (output response).
Figure 20.
Time domain performance comparison of the perturbed closed loop system with various controllers (applied input).
Table 5.
Comparison of time domain response using different controllers
Property / system Output Input
Settling time Sum of squares of amplitude (volt2) × 103 Peak amplitude(volt) Sum of squares of amplitude (volt2) × 104
Open Loop With LQG Hinf LSDP With MU Open Loop With LQG H-inf LSDP With MU With LQG H-inf LSDP MU With LQG H-inf LSDP MU
Mild strong mild strong mild strong mild strong
Nominal system 0.8 0.4 0.4 0.4 0.4 0.4 1.1 1.1 0.6 0.6 0.5 0.5 22 20 20 20 20 2 1.9 1.6 1.9 2.3
Moderately perturbed system — — — — — — 1.05 1.06 0.572 — 0.512 0.529 — — — — — 2.04 1.67 — 1.93 2.45
Highly perturbed system 0.65 0.62 0.48 0.51 0.5 0.42 1.24 1.48 0.7 0.72 0.66 0.65 22 20 20 20 20 1.85 1.26 1.25 1.59 1.63

Similarly, the power of the input voltage required to achieve this effect is 2.0 × 104 volt2, 1.92 × 104 volt2, 1.56 × 104 volt2 and 2.26 × 104 volt2 respectively for the LQG, standard H∞, H∞ LSDP and MU controllers. It can be concluded safely that H∞ LSDP controller isthe best among LQG, H∞ and MU controllers in termsof efficient use of control energy. At this stage, it appears that strength of output signal with standard H∞ is lower than that with LSDP controller. By redesigning the LSDP controller and giving slightly higher gains to it and hence giving the name a stronger LSDP controller, with almost same control energy as standard H∞, better reduction in the energy of the output signal can be obtained. Hence for the nominal system, LSDP controllers outperforms even the MU controller interms of output response with much less control energy utilization.

Similarly Figures 21 and 22 show the output response and applied input corresponding to the perturbed system with nearly simply supported boundary conditions. The OL settling time is 0.65 second for the same initial conditions as were given to the nominal system. The CL settling time obtained with LQG, standard H∞, H∞ LSDP and MU controllers are 0.62, 0.48, 0.51 and 0.42 second respectively. This means that even the LQG controller is effective for the perturbed system in terms of settling time only. However, the true efficiency of the controller which is measured in terms of strength of the output signal says something different. The sum of thesquares of the output signal of this OL system is 1.24 × 103 volt2. The strength of the output signal of the CL system with LQG controller is 1.48 × 103 volt2. In other words, the LQG controller is basically deteriorating the system performance. The corresponding values with standardH∞, strongH∞LSDP and MU controller are 0.704 × 103, 0.657 × 103 and 0.646 × 103 respectively. It is showing that these three controllers are giving stability to the CL system. The peak voltage required at the actuator side remains near 20 volt for these controllers. The power of the input voltage required to achieve this effect is 1.26 × 104 volt2, 1.59 × 104 volt2 and 1.63 × 104 volt2 respectively for the standardH∞, strongerH∞LSDP and MU controllers. With the mildH∞LSDP controller this value is 1.25 × 104 volt2. It may be concluded that the H∞LSDP controller is comparable to standardH∞ in terms of control energy utilization. Figure 21.
Time domain performance comparison of the perturbed closed loop system with various controllers (output response).
Figure 22.
Time domain performance comparison of the perturbed closed loop system with various controllers (applied input).

However, MU controller gives much better response with slightly more energy utilization. Hence when small perturbations are expected, LSDP is the appropriate controller. The control voltages which have to be applied also remain at lower values with the LSDP controller both for nominal and perturbed systems. This is also clear from Table 5 for perturbed system –I with moderate perturbations (i.e. average values for the total span of time). However, when the main aim is high performance, the MU controller gives robust performance for large perturbations to the nominal plant and that too at reasonable control energy. This thing is not easily observable from frequency domain results alone (like μ values) as noted in Table 4.

These were the calculations based on the results obtained from simulations on the MATLAB-SIMULINK software. For practical implementation on the dSPACE board, the system as well as controllers was digitized at various sampling rates and the output response was observed along with applied input. Table 6 shows the time domain parameters of the OL and CL system with different controllers at sampling rate in the range 7–10 kHz. The digitized controllers from MATAB environment were downloaded to the dSPACE board. The experiment was repeated many times and the average values obtained as noted in this table. Table 6.
Comparison of time domain response using different controllers digitized at different sampling rates
Property / system Sum of squares of amplitude of output (volt2) × 102 Sum of squares of amplitude of input (volt2) × 104
OL H-inf LSDP MU H-inf LSDP MU
10 kHz Nominal system 6.41 3.1 2.82 2.85 1.72 1.71 1.99
Perturbed system-II 10.2 5.9 5.49 5.05 1.01 1.43 1.79
8 kHz Nominal system 5.17 2.75 2.55 2.51 1.76 1.78 1.96
Perturbed system-II 8.22 4.86 4.55 4.27 0.87 1.22 1.72
7 kHz Nominal system 4.54 2.82 2.77 2.49 2.12 2.35 2.28
Perturbed system-II 7.22 4.37 4.12 3.98 0.82 1.13 1.8

The strength of the output signal for a nominal OL case was 6.41 volt2 at a sampling frequency of 10 kHz. The corresponding values of the CL system forH∞, LSDP and MU controller were 3.10, 2.82 and 2.85 volt2 respectively. The strength of the applied input for the above cited controllers was 1.72, 1.71 and 1.99 volt2 respectively. It implies that for same control energy LSDP controller performed the best. After that the controllers were tested for the perturbed system-II. The strength of the output signal corresponding to the OL system was 10.2 volt2. The corresponding values of the perturbed CL system for the above controllers were 5.90, 5.49 and 5.05 respectively. The strength of the applied input for the above cited controllers was 1.01, 1.43 and 1.79 volt2 respectively. The performance was worst with H∞ controller and best with MU controller. So, the digitized MU controller was performing robustly for a highly perturbed system and that also at reasonably more energy utilization (Table 6). The results are well matching with theoretical simulations. From the above results, it is obvious that when there is a constraint on the control energy used, mild perturbations from nominal values are expected and superior robust performance is not the aim. Any of H∞ or LSDP controllers can be applied. Since LSDP is energy efficient for a nominal system as well as moderately perturbed systems, this should be given the first performance. On the other hand, if a superior robust performance is the only aim and large perturbations are expected from the nominal values, the MU controller should be given the first priority.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: In the present work, relative merits and demerits of LQG, standard H∞, H∞ LSDP and MU-synthesis controllers have been discussed. The controllers designed are digitized at a specific sampling frequency and implemented experimentally using dSPACE based rapid prototyping system. System parameters are varied through artificial means. It has been observed that everything cannot be explained based on the results in frequency domain. Time domain results also explain some of the important facts. Strength of the output signal and energy utilized by the actuators are some of the important parameters to quantify the efficiency of different controllers. It was observed that LQG controllers should never be used for systems with expected large variation in system parameters. Standard H∞, LSDP and MU controllers can be tried to give good stability and performance for systems with perturbations from the nominal system. Almost equal CL performance is achievable with these controllers. Control energy utilization is worst in case of MU controller when applied to a system with minor perturbations around the nominal value. The best thing observed is that H∞ loop shaping based controller is best in terms of control energy utilization. H∞ loop shaping based controller not only outperforms in terms of stability, but also maintains best performance, even for a moderate variation in system parameters with a minimum amount of control energy utilization. However, for systems with expected large variations from the nominal model, MU controller is the best choice.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
